sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Vocal cord paralysis (VCP) is a common cause of congenital stridor, second in frequency to laryngomalacia.1 Familial VCP, however, is rare. Most reported cases have demonstrated autosomal dominant inheritance with cognitive, neurologic, or physical abnormalities in the affected subjects.2 We present a case of probable X-linked familial bilateral VCP in an otherwise normal female neonate whose affected relatives also have no other mental or physical deficits. We also conclude with a discussion of familial VCP, its management, and the apparent inheritance pattern in our patient.

sec.title: Case
sec.p: The patient was a 2335-gram, full-term female born by uneventful vaginal delivery. She immediately developed stridor with desaturations to the 60s. Flexible laryngoscopy revealed bilateral laryngeal abductor paralysis, and she required a tracheotomy on day of life 3. Her brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), chest radiograph, and chromosome analysis were normal. The remainder of her hospitalization was unremarkable, and she was eventually discharged home on room air via tracheostomy collar.

There is no known parental consanguinity in the family, and no paternal family members have VCP. Maternal family history reveals a male cousin and uncle with bilateral VCP requiring tracheostomy during infancy. Both regained vocal cord function and were decannulated at ages 2 and 5 years, respectively. A great uncle had “breathing problems” during infancy. All affected relatives displayed no dysmorphic features. An otherwise normal younger sister of the propositus was born with bilateral vocal cord paresis and is thriving well without a tracheostomy (Figure 1).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The nucleus ambiguus contains the neurons that supply the laryngeal abductor and adductor muscles and is the proposed lesion site for familial VCP. Fewer neurons innervate the abductors (posterior cricoarytenoid muscles) than the adductors (cricoarytenoid, thyroarytenoid, and cricothyroid muscles), making laryngeal abduction more vulnerable to genetic aberration.1,3

Before genetic evaluation, the airway needs urgent assessment and management. As in our index case, a tracheotomy is indicated in severely symptomatic patients after confirmation of bilateral laryngeal abductor paralysis on fiber-optic laryngoscopy. Affected individuals may have partial or full recovery of vocal fold function by early childhood, possibly because of maturation of the neuromuscular pathway involved in normal vocal fold movement.1,2,4,5 However, if the paralysis does not resolve spontaneously, arytenoidectomy, vocal cord lateralization, or cordectomy may be considered to allow for decannulation.2 An MRI of the brain and a chest radiograph are also necessary to exclude secondary causes of bilateral VCP such as an Arnold–Chiari malformation, thoracic vascular malformation, or a mediastinal mass, as the medical management of each entity is considerably different.

Genetic consultation is warranted in cases of suspected familial VCP. Pedigree analysis helps discover other affected family members, determine the mode of transmission, and estimate the recurrence risk in future pregnancies. X-linked recessive, autosomal recessive, and autosomal dominant inheritance have been described in past reports. DNA testing should also be considered as allelic variations that underlie familial VCP may be discovered. Previous studies have associated the autosomal dominant form of bilateral VCP with a locus on chromosome 6. In 1978, Mace et al6 proposed linkage of familial laryngeal adductor paralysis to human leukocyte antigen (HLA) on chromosome 6p21. In 2001, Manaligod et al7 discovered an allele on chromosome 6q16, which occurred with higher incidence in affected individuals.

The few cases of X-linked familial VCP report coexisting mental deficiency, musculoskeletal anomalies, or neurologic abnormalities.3,8-10 This case describes likely X-linked familial bilateral VCP without associated deficits. X-linked inheritance is suspected because most affected individuals are males on the maternal side of the family. The presentation of an X-linked disorder in a female may be because of X-inactivation patterns with variable expression among the affected family members.

Familial bilateral VCP is a rare disorder that typically presents in the neonatal period. Symptomatic individuals warrant an airway evaluation and management with tracheostomy if necessary. Airway patency and vocal cord movement usually improves or normalizes by toddler age, allowing for decannulation. Various modes of inheritance have been described, and the few X-linked cases report coexisting neurologic or physical anomalies. We believe our patient has familial X-linked abductor vocal cord paralysis without associated comorbidities. Further genetic studies, including X-inactivation analysis of affected and unaffected family members may provide insight into the mechanism of genetic transmission.
